12.26.text:
Well, thank you, Neera,
for the wonderful introduction

15.26.text:
and sharing a story
that resonated with me.

19.39.text:
There were a lot
of parallels in my life

21.63.text:
and probably resonated
with some of you.

25.33.text:
Over the past 10 years,
the Center for American Progress

29.29.text:
has done incredible
work to shape the debate

32.53.text:
over expanding opportunity
for all Americans.

35.46.text:
And I could not be
more grateful to CAP

38.19.text:
not only for giving me

42.02.text:
but also

47.49.text:
My friend, John Podesta,

51.63.text:
my Chief of Staff,
Denis McDonough,

56.33.text:
So you guys are obviously doing

59.73.text:
I also want to thank

63.43.text:

65.29.text:
for the wonderful
work that they do.

67.46.text: I want to thank Mayor Gray

69.69.text:
and everyone here at
THEARC for having me.

73.33.text:
This center,
which I've been to quite a bit,

75.33.text:
have had a chance to see some of

And all the nonprofits that

85.36.text:
to everything from

88.22.text:
to a safe shelter
from the streets,

91.16.text:
which means that you're

97.46.text:
And your work

104.76.text:
a belief that we're greater
together than we are on our own.

108.59.text:
And that's what I've come
here to talk about today.

112.29.text:
Over the last two months,
Washington has been dominated

117.06.text: I think that's fair to say.

120.59.text:
And between a reckless shutdown
by congressional Republicans

124.19.text:
in an effort to repeal
the Affordable Care Act,

127.59.text:
and admittedly poor execution
on my administration's part

130.43.text:
in implementing the latest
stage of the new law,

133.83.text:
nobody has acquitted themselves
very well these past few months.

137.22.text:
So it's not surprising that the
American people's frustrations

141.76.text:
with Washington
are at an all-time high.

145.36.text:
But we know that people's
frustrations run deeper

150.53.text:
than these most recent
political battles.

154.06.text:
Their frustration is rooted
in their own daily battles --

157.89.text:
to make ends meet,
to pay for college, buy a home,

166.22.text:
It's rooted in
the nagging sense

167.89.text:
that no matter
how hard they work,

170.43.text:
the deck is stacked
against them.

172.79.text:
And it's rooted in
the fear that their kids

175.63.text:
won't be better
off than they were.

180.19.text:
They may not follow the constant
back-and-forth in Washington

185.73.text:
but they experience
in a very personal

195.93.text:
that I want to spend some
time talking about today.

197.69.text:
And that is a dangerous and
growing inequality and lack

200.93.text:
of upward mobility that
has jeopardized middle-class

207.53.text:
that if you work hard,
you have a chance to get ahead.

212.33.text:
I believe this is the defining
challenge of our time:

216.46.text:
Making sure our economy works
for every working American.

222.19.text: It's why I ran for President.

224.79.text:
It was at the center
of last year's campaign.

227.89.text:
It drives everything
I do in this office.

230.19.text:
And I know I've raised
this issue before,

234.99.text:
and some will ask why I raise
the issue again right now.

239.53.text:
I do it because the
outcomes of the debates

243.16.text:
whether it's health care,
or the budget,

245.86.text:
or reforming our housing
and financial systems --

248.36.text:
all these things will have
real, practical implications

252.16.text:
And I am convinced that the
decisions we make on these

256.12.text:
issues over the next few years
will determine whether or not

258.79.text:
our children will
grow up in an America

267.69.text:
Now, the premise
that we're all created equal

272.56.text:
is the opening line
in the American story.

276.43.text:
And while we don't
promise equal outcomes,

280.39.text:
we have strived to
deliver equal opportunity --

284.63.text:
the idea that success
doesn't depend on being born

289.89.text: it depends on effort and merit.

291.63.text:
And with every chapter
we've added to that story,

296.96.text:
we've worked hard to put
those words into practice.

306.86.text:
who started a system
of land grant colleges

310.29.text:
so that any poor man's son
could go learn something new.

315.79.text:
When farms gave
way to factories,

317.22.text:
a rich man's son named
Teddy Roosevelt fought

320.59.text:
for an eight-hour workday,
protections for workers,

324.89.text:
and busted monopolies that
kept prices high and wages low.

330.16.text:
When millions lived in poverty,
FDR fought for Social Security,

333.26.text:
and insurance for the
unemployed, and a minimum wage.

337.53.text:
When millions died
without health insurance,

339.76.text:
LBJ fought for
Medicare and Medicaid.

344.96.text:
Together, we forged a New Deal,
declared a War on Poverty

353.59.text:
We built a ladder of
opportunity to climb,

356.39.text:
and stretched out a safety net
beneath so that if we fell,

360.93.text:
it wouldn't be too far,
and we could bounce back.

364.76.text:
And as a result, America built
the largest middle class

370.26.text:
And for the three decades
after World War II,

372.59.text:
it was the engine
of our prosperity.

376.76.text:
Now, we can't look at the past
through rose-colored glasses.

379.99.text:
The economy didn't
always work for everyone.

384.33.text:
Racial discrimination locked
millions out of poverty --

390.69.text:
Women were too often
confined to a handful

395.33.text:
And it was only through
painstaking struggle

400.56.text:
and Americans with disabilities
began to win the right

403.19.text:
to more fairly and fully
participate in the economy.

409.36.text:
Nevertheless, during the
post-World War II years,

412.49.text:
the economic ground felt stable
and secure for most Americans,

417.36.text:
and the future looked
brighter than the past.

421.63.text:
And for some,
that meant following

423.69.text:
in your old man's footsteps
at the local plant,

427.12.text:
and you knew that
a blue-collar job

429.16.text:
would let you
buy a home, and a car,

432.19.text:
maybe a vacation once
in a while, health care,

439.02.text:
For others,
it meant going to college --

440.69.text:
in some cases, maybe the first
in your family to go to college.

444.09.text:
And it meant graduating without
taking on loads of debt,

449.39.text:
and being able to
count on advancement

456.39.text:
Now, it's true that those at
the top, even in those years,

459.59.text:
claimed a much larger share
of income than the rest:

463.39.text:
The top 10 percent consistently
took home about one-third

469.53.text:
But that kind of inequality
took place in a dynamic market

472.36.text:
economy where everyone's wages
and incomes were growing.

478.93.text:
And because of upward mobility,
the guy on the factory floor

482.33.text:
could picture his kid
running the company some day.

488.83.text:
this social compact
began to unravel.

494.99.text:
Technology made it easier for
companies to do more with less,

504.39.text:
A more competitive world lets
companies ship jobs anywhere.

512.29.text:
And as good manufacturing jobs
automated or headed offshore,

516.19.text:
workers lost their
leverage, jobs paid less

524.26.text:
As values of
community broke down,

528.89.text:
businesses lobbied Washington to
weaken unions and the value

535.63.text:
As a trickle-down ideology
became more prominent,

538.19.text:
taxes were slashed
for the wealthiest,

540.76.text:
while investments in things
that make us all richer,

543.56.text:
like schools and infrastructure,
were allowed to wither.

549.12.text:
And for a certain
period of time,

550.36.text:
we could ignore this
weakening economic foundation,

555.83.text:
in part because more families
were relying on two earners

566.02.text:
We took on more debt financed
by a juiced-up housing market.

570.53.text:
But when the music stopped,
and the crisis hit,

574.83.text:
of whatever cushion
they had left.

576.16.text:
And the result is an economy
that's become profoundly

582.73.text:
unequal, and families
that are more insecure.

586.16.text:
I'll just give you
a few statistics.

589.66.text:
Since 1979, when I
graduated from high school,

594.93.text:
our productivity is up
by more than 90 percent,

599.56.text:
but the income of the typical
family has increased

606.19.text:
Since 1979, our economy has
more than doubled in size,

612.29.text:
but most of that growth has
flowed to a fortunate few.

616.73.text:
The top 10 percent
no longer takes in

619.43.text:
one-third of our income --
it now takes half.

625.46.text:
Whereas in the past, the average
CEO made about 20 to 30 times

629.63.text:
the income of the
average worker,

631.66.text:
today's CEO now
makes 273 times more.

637.26.text:
And meanwhile, a family in the
top 1 percent has a net worth

640.69.text:
288 times higher than
the typical family,

644.06.text:
which is a record
for this country.

648.09.text:
So the basic bargain at the
heart of our economy has frayed.

654.12.text:
In fact, this trend towards
growing inequality is not unique

659.33.text:
Across the developed world,
inequality has increased.

664.22.text:
Some of you may have
seen just last week,

666.46.text:
the Pope himself spoke about
this at eloquent length.

673.39.text:
"How can it be," he wrote,
"that it is not a news item

676.33.text:
when an elderly homeless
person dies of exposure,

679.36.text:
but it is news when the stock
market loses two points?"

685.33.text:
But this increasing
inequality is most pronounced

689.19.text:
in our country, and it
challenges the very essence

693.73.text: of who we are as a people.

698.09.text:
Understand we've never
begrudged success in America.

703.22.text:
We admire folks who start
new businesses, create jobs,

707.86.text:
and invent the products
that enrich our lives.

711.12.text:
And we expect them to be
rewarded handsomely for it.

716.66.text:
In fact, we've often accepted
more income inequality than many

719.86.text:
other nations for
one big reason --

722.99.text:
because we were convinced
that America is a place

725.33.text:
where even if you're
born with nothing,

726.86.text:
with a little hard work you
can improve your own situation

729.83.text:
over time and build something
better to leave your kids.

734.59.text:
As Lincoln once said,
"While we do not propose

738.76.text:
we do wish to allow the
humblest man an equal chance

741.76.text:
to get rich with
everybody else."

747.56.text:
The problem is that alongside
increased inequality,

750.93.text:
we've seen diminished levels of
upward mobility in recent years.

756.36.text:
A child born in the
top 20 percent

761.12.text:
has about a 2-in-3 chance of
staying at or near the top.

766.59.text:
A child born into the
bottom 20 percent has

769.43.text:
a less than 1-in-20 shot
at making it to the top.

774.36.text:
He's 10 times likelier
to stay where he is.

776.93.text:
In fact, statistics
show not only

780.53.text:
that our levels of
income inequality

782.29.text:
rank near countries
like Jamaica and Argentina,

787.43.text:
but that it is harder today for
a child born here in America

792.63.text:
to improve her station
in life than it is for children

795.73.text: in most of our wealthy allies --

797.46.text:
countries like Canada
or Germany or France.

799.83.text:
They have greater mobility
than we do, not less.

807.12.text:
The idea that so many children
are born into poverty

809.26.text:
in the wealthiest nation on
Earth is heartbreaking enough.

813.56.text:
But the idea that a child
may never be able

818.56.text:
because she lacks a decent
education or health care,

822.56.text:
or a community that views
her future as their own,

825.96.text:
that should offend all of us and
it should compel us to action.

829.69.text:
We are a better
country than this.

834.43.text:
So let me repeat: The combined
trends of increased inequality

839.43.text:
and decreasing mobility pose
a fundamental threat to the

843.02.text: American Dream, our way of life,

845.06.text:
and what we stand for
around the globe.

849.39.text:
And it is not simply a moral
claim that I'm making here.

852.26.text:
There are practical consequences
to rising inequality

856.69.text:
For one thing, these trends
are bad for our economy.

862.86.text:
One study finds that
growth is more fragile

865.43.text:
and recessions are more
frequent in countries

873.93.text:
When families have
less to spend,

876.09.text:
that means businesses
have fewer customers,

879.59.text:
and households rack up greater
mortgage and credit card debt;

883.73.text:
meanwhile, concentrated wealth
at the top is less likely

886.33.text:
to result in the kind of broadly
based consumer spending

892.76.text:
may contribute to risky
speculative bubbles.

895.12.text:
And rising inequality and
declining mobility are also bad

900.99.text:
for our families and
social cohesion --

905.12.text:
not just because we tend to
trust our institutions less,

918.86.text:
And greater inequality is
associated with less mobility

922.36.text:
That means it's not just
temporary; the effects last.

929.02.text:
For example, by the time
she turns three years old,

932.53.text:
a child born into a low-income
home hears 30 million

936.96.text:
fewer words than a child
from a well-off family,

941.73.text:
which means by the time she
starts school she's already

943.96.text:
behind, and that deficit can
compound itself over time.

951.79.text:
And finally, rising inequality
and declining mobility

957.76.text:
Ordinary folks can't write
massive campaign checks

960.59.text:
or hire high-priced
lobbyists and lawyers

962.76.text:
to secure policies that tilt
the playing field in their favor

967.49.text:
And so people get the bad taste
that the system is rigged,

974.96.text:
and that increases
cynicism and polarization,

980.06.text:
and it decreases the
political participation

982.59.text:
that is a requisite part of
our system of self-government.

989.93.text:
So this is an issue that
we have to tackle head on.

996.12.text:
And if, in fact, the majority
of Americans agree

998.63.text:
that our number-one priority
is to restore opportunity

1001.49.text:
and broad-based growth
for all Americans,

1003.76.text:
the question is
why has Washington

1007.22.text:
And I think a big reason is
the myths that have developed

1021.29.text:
First, there is the myth that
this is a problem restricted

1023.83.text:
to a small share of
predominantly minority poor --

1031.86.text:
that this isn't
a broad-based problem,

1033.16.text:
this is a black problem
or a Hispanic problem

1038.12.text:
Now, it's true that the painful
legacy of discrimination means

1040.96.text:
that African Americans, Latinos,
Native Americans are far more

1044.36.text:
likely to suffer from
a lack of opportunity --

1053.93.text:
It's also true that women still
make 77 cents on the dollar

1061.09.text:
So we're going to need
strong application

1066.06.text:
We're going to need
immigration reform

1067.86.text:
that grows the economy and
takes people out of the shadows.

1070.73.text:
We're going to need targeted
initiatives to close those gaps.

1082.66.text:
The decades-long shifts in the
economy have hurt all groups:

1088.73.text:
poor and middle class;
inner city and rural folks;

1092.99.text:
men and women;
and Americans of all races.

1098.73.text:
And as a consequence,
some of the social patterns

1104.22.text:
that were once attributed
to the urban poor --

1108.02.text:
that's a particular
problem for the inner city:

1119.26.text:
it turns out now we're seeing
that pop up everywhere.

1125.89.text:
A new study shows that
disparities in education,

1129.06.text:
mental health, obesity, absent
fathers, isolation from church,

1136.83.text:
these gaps are now as much
about growing up rich or poor

1140.73.text: as they are about anything else.

1145.49.text:
The gap in test scores between
poor kids and wealthy kids

1149.29.text: is now nearly twice what it is

1151.89.text:
between white kids
and black kids.

1156.86.text:
Kids with working-class parents
are 10 times likelier

1160.29.text:
than kids with middle-
or upper-class parents

1162.79.text:
to go through a time when
their parents have no income.

1165.06.text:
So the fact is this:
The opportunity gap in America

1170.79.text:
is now as much about class
as it is about race,

1177.89.text:
So if we're going to
take on growing inequality

1180.16.text:
and try to improve upward
mobility for all people,

1183.73.text:
we've got to move
beyond the false notion

1185.86.text:
that this is an issue
exclusively of minority concern.

1192.06.text:
And we have to reject a politics
that suggests any effort to

1195.46.text:
address it in a meaningful way
somehow pits the interests

1198.06.text:
of a deserving middle
class against those

1200.76.text:
of an undeserving poor
in search of handouts.

1215.39.text:
Second, we need to dispel the
myth that the goals of growing

1218.12.text:
the economy and reducing
inequality are necessarily

1221.09.text:
in conflict, when they should
actually work in concert.

1226.26.text:
We know from our history
that our economy grows best

1230.49.text:
when growth is
more widely shared.

1232.53.text:
And we know that beyond
a certain level of inequality,

1241.19.text:
Third, we need to set aside
the belief that government

1244.26.text:
cannot do anything
about reducing inequality.

1249.09.text:
It's true that government
cannot prevent all the downsides

1251.93.text:
of the technological change
and global competition

1255.33.text: that are out there right now,

1257.29.text:
and some of those forces
are also some of the things

1263.49.text:
And it's also true that
some programs in the past,

1266.12.text:
like welfare before
it was reformed,

1268.02.text:
were sometimes poorly designed,
created disincentives to work.

1272.02.text:
But we've also seen how
government action time and again

1277.96.text:
can make an enormous difference
in increasing opportunity

1280.93.text:
and bolstering ladders
into the middle class.

1288.53.text:
collective bargaining,
and a minimum wage --

1291.29.text:
these all contributed to
rising standards of living

1300.86.text:
that every citizen
of this country deserved

1305.02.text:
a floor through which
they could not fall --

1307.79.text:
we helped millions of
Americans live in dignity,

1310.96.text:
and gave millions
more the confidence

1314.73.text:
by taking a risk
on a great idea.

1320.56.text:
Without Social Security,
nearly half of seniors

1322.76.text:
would
be living in poverty -- half.

1330.99.text:
Before Medicare,
only half of all seniors

1333.73.text:
had some form
of health insurance.

1339.99.text:
And because we've
strengthened that safety net,

1342.09.text:
and expanded pro-work and

1344.66.text:
like the Earned
Income Tax Credit,

1346.49.text:
a recent study found that
the poverty rate has fallen

1350.96.text:
And these endeavors didn't
just make us a better country;

1355.16.text:
they reaffirmed that
we are a great country.

1363.22.text:
So we can make a
difference on this.

1366.76.text:
In fact,
that's our generation's task --

1369.73.text:
to rebuild America's
economic and civic foundation

1373.16.text:
to continue the expansion of
opportunity for this generation

1379.39.text:
And like Neera,
I take this personally.

1389.56.text:
I'm only here because
this country

1391.29.text:
educated my grandfather
on the GI Bill.

1396.19.text:
When my father left and
my mom hit hard times trying

1398.89.text:
to raise my sister and me
while she was going to school,

1401.16.text:
this country helped make
sure we didn't go hungry.

1405.36.text:
When Michelle, the daughter of
a shift worker at a water plant

1409.09.text:
and a secretary, wanted to
go to college, just like me,

1414.26.text:
this country helped us afford
it until we could pay it back.

1420.19.text:
So what drives me as
a grandson, a son, a father --

1425.66.text:
is to make sure that
every striving, hardworking,

1430.56.text:
has the same incredible chance
that this country gave me.

1438.39.text: It has been the driving force

1449.43.text:
between everything we've
done these past five years.

1452.93.text:
And over the course
of the next year,

1454.19.text:
and for the rest
of my presidency,

1455.86.text:
that's where you should
expect my administration

1462.53.text:
Now, you'll be pleased
to know this is not

1469.59.text: a State of the Union Address.

1474.33.text:
And many of the ideas that can
make the biggest difference

1477.66.text:
in expanding opportunity
I've presented before.

1481.02.text:
But let me offer
a few key principles,

1482.76.text:
just a roadmap that I believe
should guide us in both

1484.99.text:
our legislative agenda
and our administrative efforts.

1489.49.text:
To begin with,
we have to continue

1491.26.text:
to relentlessly push
a growth agenda.

1496.22.text:
It may be true that
in today's economy,

1498.33.text:
growth alone does not guarantee
higher wages and incomes.

1503.63.text:
But what's also true
is we can't tackle inequality

1506.19.text:
if the economic pie
is shrinking or stagnant.

1511.12.text:
The fact is if you're a
progressive and you want to help

1513.69.text:
the middle class
and the working poor,

1516.22.text:
you've still got to be concerned
about competitiveness

1522.63.text:
And that's why from
day one we've worked

1526.93.text:
to get the economy growing
and help our businesses hire.

1530.49.text:
And thanks to their
resilience and innovation,

1533.26.text:
they've created nearly
8 million new jobs

1536.22.text:
And now we've got to grow
the economy even faster.

1539.33.text:
And we've got to keep working to
make America a magnet for good,

1542.89.text:
middle-class jobs
to replace the ones

1544.99.text:
that we've lost
in recent decades --

1550.66.text:
And that means simplifying
our corporate tax code

1554.76.text:
in a way that closes
wasteful loopholes

1556.73.text:
and ends incentives
to ship jobs overseas.

1560.73.text:
And by broadening the base,
we can actually lower rates

1567.33.text:
to encourage more
companies to hire here

1569.83.text:
and use some of
the money we save

1571.06.text:
to create good jobs
rebuilding our roads

1573.36.text:
and our bridges
and our airports,

1575.02.text:
and all the infrastructure
our businesses need.
